metadata.case_name: Petitions by three groups of persons against Hyderabad High Court judgments in Criminal Cases Nos. 14, 17 and 18 of 1949
metadata.case_number: Petitions Nos. 12, 13 and 14 of 1951 (Art. 32); Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 14, 15 and 16 (Art. 136)

facts.text: On 30th October 1948, Military Governor of Hyderabad enacted Special Tribunals Regulation No. 5 of 1358 F, amended on 22nd May 1949, 10th July 1949, 23rd July 1949 and 30th October 1949.
Regulation empowered Military Governor to constitute Special Tribunals of three members to try offences committed before or after commencement; Section 8 allowed delegation to other authorities.
Tribunal A constituted for Nalgonda district; Civil Administrator of Nalgonda made over cases to it under powers from Military Governor.

Criminal Case No. 14 of 1949 based on charge sheet No. 14 dated 7th April 1949: Accused in khaki uniform with unnotified firearms went to village on 21st September 1948, caught four persons for not paying subscription, killed them by cutting throats.

Criminal Case No. 17 of 1949 based on charge sheets Nos. 14 and 15 dated 20th July 1949: On 6th April 1949, two accused fired guns in village, joined others, marched on villagers, fired indiscriminately killing one and injuring another; trial version: chased by villagers, fired in self-defense.
Criminal Case No. 18 of 1949: On 15th May 1949 midnight, accused in khaki with firearms took Natala Rama Reddy from terrace, killed him by gunshots despite protests.
Petitioners convicted of murder and sentenced to death, also for other offences including carrying unlicensed firearms; appeals to Hyderabad High Court confirmed convictions on 19th December 1950.

Applications for leave to appeal to Judicial Committee pending when Constitution came into force; amended to seek leave under Art. 134, rejected; special leave under Art. 136 dismissed as no jurisdiction pre-26 Jan 1950; Art. 226 petitions rejected.

Civil Administrator letter No. 3176/49-ST dated 7th April 1949 made over charge sheets Nos. 1-14 to Tribunal; letter No. 4234/49-ST dated 23rd July 1949 made over Nos. 15-40; no specific order for charge sheet No. 14 dated 20th July 1949 (Case 17).
In Cases 17 and 18, accused not defended by counsel; informed on 3rd August 1949 to prepare defence by 6th/7th August; trials concluded 13th/14th August 1949.
Affidavit by Hanumantha Naidu: Accused had means or facilities to engage lawyers; some declined; lawyers willing.
In Case 14, accused defended by pleader Ramireddy for some.
High Court proceedings: Accused declined lawyers even in appeal.
Amending Regulation 30th October 1949: Death sentences by hanging; warrants in form Tribunal thinks fit.
Case 17 had six accused; five also in Case 18; only Kallur Gowndla Elladu uniquely affected by jurisdiction issue; no definite overt acts attributed to him for murder.

legal_issues.text: Whether Special Tribunal had jurisdiction to try the cases, particularly due to lack of specific order making over charge sheet No. 14 dated 20th July 1949 for Case 17.
Whether fair trial denied in Cases 17 and 18 due to no opportunity to instruct counsel and undefended throughout.
Whether misjoinder of charges, especially unlicensed firearms with murder.
Whether death sentence by hanging illegal; must be by decapitation per Hyderabad CrPC Schedule IV Form 29.
Whether death sentence executable without 'manzuri' (assent) of H.E.H. the Nizam per Hyderabad CrPC ss.20,302,307.
Whether relief under Art. 32 available post final High Court judgment pre-Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Trial by Special Tribunal without jurisdiction as Civil Administrator's orders did not specifically identify petitioners' cases by name, only charge sheet numbers.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Special Tribunals Regulation; ordinary procedure requires Magistrate enquiry then Sessions.

petitioner_arguments.text: No fair trial in Cases 17/18: No opportunity to communicate with relations/friends, no counsel offered or appointed; ignorant of rights.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hyderabad CrPC s.271; Powell v. Alabama (US due process).

petitioner_arguments.text: Misjoinder of charges: Unlicensed firearms unconnected to murders, not same transaction.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Subramania Iyer v. King Emperor; CrPC s.234.

petitioner_arguments.text: Death by hanging illegal; only decapitation per Hyderabad CrPC s.311 Schedule IV Form 29.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hyderabad Penal Code s.243; CrPC s.311.

petitioner_arguments.text: 'Manzuri' of Nizam required for death sentence; not obtained.

respondent_arguments.text: Charge sheet numbers sufficient to identify cases; specific transfer for all including Case 17.
Facilities given to engage lawyers; accused had means or declined; lawyers willing and appeared in Case 14.
No misjoinder or prejudice; not jurisdictional defect.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Abdul Rahman v. King Emperor; Babu Lal v. Emperor.

respondent_arguments.text: Amending Regulation allows hanging retrospectively; High Court could impose.
'Manzuri' replaced by 'tausiq' (confirmation) by Military Governor; no Nizam assent needed.

court_reasoning.text: Misjoinder not jurisdictional defect; even if irregular, appealable; High Court confirmed, final.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Basic difference between want of jurisdiction and irregular exercise; no authority for writ on procedural non-compliance.

court_reasoning.text: Death by hanging valid post-amendment; retrospective as mode not substantive; High Court power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Amending Regulation s.2-B applies to unexecuted sentences.

court_reasoning.text: 'Manzuri' means confirmation; replaced by 'tausiq' in Regulation; simplifies procedure.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Word used for High Court/Govt too, not peculiar to Nizam.

court_reasoning.text: No absolute rule that unrepresented accused in capital case vitiates trial; depends on handicap amounting to no fair trial; here accused declined, facilities given.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not every unrepresented case bad; appellate court can assess.

court_reasoning.text: Charge sheet references sufficient; but prima facie no order for Case 17 charge sheet 14(2); however, no Art.32 relief as High Court finality pre-Constitution; habeas not available post-conviction upheld on appeal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Finality of judgments; cannot reopen via Art.32 what appeal process closed.

court_reasoning.text: Art.32 only for enforcing fundamental rights; writs not to review final pre-Constitution judgments; detention per established procedure.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot do indirectly what direct appeal denied.

holdings.text: Procedural defects like misjoinder, mode of execution, confirmation not grounds for Art.32 relief post-appellate confirmation.
No legal mandate for counsel assignment in every capital case absent request/handicap; trial not vitiated here.
Even assuming jurisdiction defect in Case 17, no habeas/Art.32 relief as High Court judgment final; appellate court competent even if wrong.
Art.32 not to reopen final pre-Constitution criminal judgments.

precedents_cited.relevance: Misjoinder due to 41 offences; restricted by later cases.
US due process requires counsel in capital cases; not binding.
No habeas to challenge jurisdiction post-conviction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Greene v. Secretary of State for Home Affairs
precedents_cited.relevance: No habeas if detention per criminal sentence.
Return stating detention per conviction sufficient.
Return stating detention per conviction sufficient.
Affidavits on jurisdiction; but appellate confirmation binds.

statutes_cited.name: Special Tribunals Regulation No. 5 of 1358 F
statutes_cited.relevance: Constituted tribunals, delegated powers, confirmation by Governor, hanging for death.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for petitions; only for fundamental rights enforcement, no review of final pre-Constitution judgments.

statutes_cited.name: Hyderabad Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Death as penalty for murder, no mode specified.

statutes_cited.name: Hyderabad Criminal Procedure Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Right to pleader; execution warrants decapitation; manzuri (confirmation) required; finality of appellate judgments.

outcome.summary: Petitions under Art.32 and for special leave under Art.136 dismissed; no relief as High Court judgments final pre-Constitution, procedural defects not invocable under Art.32, jurisdiction/counsel issues not sufficient for habeas post-appellate confirmation.

key_quotes.text: There is a basic difference between want of jurisdiction and an illegal or irregular exercise of jurisdiction.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes defects not warranting collateral attack.

key_quotes.text: It cannot be laid down as a rule of law that in every capital case where the accused is unrepresented, the trial should be held to be vitiated.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: No absolute right to counsel absent prejudice.

key_quotes.text: The power given to this Court under this provision [Art.32(2)] is a large one, but it has to be exercised in accordance with well established principles.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits Art.32 to fundamental rights enforcement.

key_quotes.text: Can then a new law or a change in the old law entitle us to reopen a transaction which has become closed and final?
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Constitution not retrospective on final judgments.
